metadata.title: RFC: Kafka 3.6 Migration (StreamNext)
metadata.author: Nina Zhao (Staff Engineer)
metadata.reviewers: Derek Faulkner, Olumide Adeyemi, Tomás Reyes, Carlos Medina

entities: Consumer groups: 23 active (supply-chain-ingest, rec-engine-features, analytics-pipeline, etc.)
actions: RFC proposes 3-phase migration: Phase A (Oct 6-17) — deploy KRaft controllers alongside ZooKeeper, Phase B (Oct 20-31) — dual-write to both coordination layers, Phase C (Nov 3-7) — decommission ZooKeeper
Nina Zhao cataloged all 23 consumer groups and their Kafka client library versions; 19 use confluent-kafka 2.3+, 4 use older librdkafka 1.9 requiring upgrade
Rollback plan: at any phase, revert Terraform state and restart brokers with ZooKeeper coordination; estimated rollback time 45 minutes
Schema Registry migration: no changes needed, compatible with both coordination modes
Nina Zhao estimated 40 engineer-hours for the migration plus 16 hours for consumer library upgrades across 4 services
quotes: Nina Zhao: 'The 4 services on librdkafka 1.9 are the long pole. Two of them are in the analytics pipeline and the other two are in the notification service. I have already talked to both team leads and they can do the upgrade in S19.'
Olumide Adeyemi (inline comment): 'I can have the KRaft controller Terraform module ready by Oct 3. The tricky part is the security group changes — KRaft uses port 9093 for controller communication.'
Derek Faulkner: 'Approved with the condition that we do not start Phase B until all 23 consumer groups have confirmed compatibility. No exceptions.'
details: Current Kafka metrics: 142 topics, 1.8TB daily throughput, avg message size 2.4KB, peak 12K msg/sec on supply-chain-events
ZooKeeper incident history: 14 incidents in last 12 months (3 split-brain, 5 session timeouts, 4 disk full, 2 GC pauses)
KRaft benefits: eliminates ZooKeeper dependency, reduces operational complexity, faster controller failover (2s vs 12s)
Cost impact: decommissioning 3 ZooKeeper nodes saves $1,140/month ($380/node × 3, r5.large instances)
Testing plan: dedicated Kafka test cluster (3 brokers) for dry run, production-like traffic replay using recorded supply-chain-events topic

actions: Wei Lin posted a root cause analysis for the Greystone PDF rendering bug: Headless Chrome v128 changed the default image loading timeout from 30s to 10s, causing chart images to timeout on slow queries
Aisha Okonkwo suggested adding an explicit waitForSelector on chart SVG elements before triggering the PDF render
Tomás Reyes approved the approach and assigned PLAT-2970 to Wei Lin, target: fix merged by Sep 24
Raj Bhatt added the PDF rendering scenario to the E2E suite with a 6-chart dashboard fixture to catch regressions
quotes: Wei Lin: 'Found it. Chrome 128 changed `Page.setDefaultNavigationTimeout` behavior. Our Puppeteer config was relying on the old 30s default. The charts with slow underlying queries are the ones that go blank. :magnifying_glass:'
Aisha Okonkwo: 'Classic. We should add a `waitForSelector('.chart-rendered')` gate before calling `page.pdf()`. That way we wait for actual content, not a timer.'
Raj Bhatt: 'I will add a test case with a 6-chart dashboard that includes a deliberately slow query. If any chart is blank in the PDF output, the test fails. :white_check_mark:'
details: Affected customers: Greystone Logistics (confirmed), possibly others using scheduled PDF export with complex dashboards
Chrome version in production PDF service: v128.0.6613.84
Fix approach: explicit waitForSelector + configurable per-chart timeout (default 30s)
PLAT-2970 priority: P2, estimated 2 story points

metadata.title: Anomaly Detection v2 (Sentinel) — Design Phase Kickoff
metadata.author: Kendra Holloway (Director of Product)
metadata.reviewers: Derek Faulkner, Nina Zhao, Carlos Medina, Hannah Voss

actions: Kendra Holloway circulated the Sentinel design kickoff document outlining the vision: replace rule-based anomaly detection with ML-driven detection that learns customer-specific patterns

Current v1 system: 23 static rules (e.g., shipment delay >2 std dev, inventory below safety stock, cost variance >15%), generates ~340 alerts/day across all customers, 62% false positive rate per customer feedback
Sentinel v2 proposal: per-customer Isolation Forest model trained on 90 days of historical data, complemented by Prophet time-series forecasting for seasonal adjustment
Carlos Medina will lead the ML architecture; estimated 3-month engineering effort starting Q1 2026
Hannah Voss provided customer pain points: top 3 complaints are too many false positives (62%), alerts not actionable (44%), no severity ranking (38%)
Design phase deliverables: ML architecture doc by Nov 15, data pipeline design by Nov 30, prototype on 1 customer dataset by Dec 20
quotes: Kendra Holloway: 'Our customers are drowning in alerts. 340 alerts per day with a 62% false positive rate means teams are ignoring the system entirely. Sentinel needs to cut false positives below 20% to be credible.'

Carlos Medina: 'Isolation Forest is a good starting point because it handles high-dimensional supply chain data well and does not require labeled anomalies. We can train unsupervised on normal patterns and flag deviations.'
Hannah Voss: 'Brightline Retail told me they turned off anomaly alerts entirely because the noise was unbearable. If we fix this, we recover a major feature that customers have given up on.'

Nina Zhao: 'The data pipeline is the hard part. We need to materialize 90 days of per-customer features nightly without blowing up our compute budget. I want to reuse the Feast infrastructure we built for rec engine.'
details: Current v1 alert volume: 340 alerts/day average, 62% false positive rate, top 3 alert types: shipment delay (38%), inventory anomaly (29%), cost variance (18%)
Sentinel target metrics: false positive rate <20%, alert volume reduction >50%, mean time to action <30 minutes (current: 2.4 hours)
ML model candidates: Isolation Forest (primary), Prophet (seasonal adjustment), DBSCAN (cluster-based fallback)
Training data requirements: 90 days per customer, ~2.1TB total across all enterprise accounts, feature extraction from 8 source tables
Competitive landscape: ChainIQ launched ML anomaly detection in Jun 2025 (reported 35% false positive rate), LogiSense has it on 2026 roadmap
